componenttext: Welcome to the Goodyear Tire & Rubber Company's second quarter financial results conference call. All lines have been placed on mute to prevent any background noise. After the speakers ' remarks, there will be a question-and-answer session. (Operator Instructions) I will now hand the floor to Patrick Stobb, Director of Investor Relations. Thank you. Mr. Stobb, please go ahead.

headline: Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning everyone and welcome to Goodyear's second quarter conference call. With me today are Richard Kramer, President and CEO and Darren Wells, Executive Vice President and CFO. Before we get started, there are a few items I would like to cover. To
componenttext:
Good morning everyone and welcome to Goodyear's second quarter conference call. With me today are Richard Kramer, President and CEO and Darren Wells, Executive Vice President and CFO. Before we get started, there are a few items I would like to cover. To begin the web cast of this morning's discussion and supporting slides presentation can be found at our website at investor.goodyear.com.
A replay of this call will be accessible later today. Replay instructions were included in our earnings release issued earlier this morning. The last item, we plan to file a 10-Q later today. If I can now direct your attention to the Safe harbor statement on slide two of the presentation.
Our discussion this morning may contain forward looking statements, based on our current expectations and assumptions and are subject to risks and uncertainties that can cause actual results to differ materially. These risks and uncertainties are outlined in Goodyear’s filings with the SEC and the news release we issued this morning.
The company disclaims any intention or obligation to update or revise any forward-looking statements, whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise.
Turning now to the agenda. On today's call, Rich will provide a business review. After Rich’s remark, Darren will, in fact, will discuss the financial results and outlook before opening the call to your questions. That finishes my comments and I will now turn the call over to Rich.

headline: Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Pat and good morning to everyone. I’ll separate my remarks this morning into three sections. First, I’ll highlight our strong second quarter results which are very gratifying, then I will offer some observations on what I see in our markets
componenttext:
Thank you, Pat and good morning to everyone. I’ll separate my remarks this morning into three sections. First, I’ll highlight our strong second quarter results which are very gratifying, then I will offer some observations on what I see in our markets in the economy. And finally I will share with you some reflections of my first 100 days on the job and how my discussions and observations over the past three months have increased our confidence in our business, our industry, our team and finally our earnings prospects.
First, let’s highlight our strong second quarter results. During the second quarter, we achieved significant progress across all our businesses driven by a combination of sales growth and cost actions versus the comparable prior year period, sales were up 15%, units up 10% and segment operating income was $219 million, an improvement of more than 190 million for the second quarter 2009.
This kind of performance demonstrates that we have pulled the right levers during the economic downturn and that our actions have us well positioned for growth opportunities presented by the recovery.
From an operational standpoint, our performance was driven by our ability to capture the benefits of recovering industry demand in terms of sales volume and factory utilization. The continued use of award winning new products in all of our regions, delivering price increases and mix improvements through a relentless focus on brands and channels to address escalating raw material costs and delivering productivity improvements resulting from continued focus on sustainable cost reduction programs.
Some particular highlights of our performances include stronger results in our North America business where segment operating income was $16 million, which was more than $100 million improvement over the prior period. I point out that the improvement would be even more impressive, were it not for a $20 million impact from an unforeseen adverse procedural ruling on a six-year-old product liability case which we continue to contest.
Our North American business continued to focus on innovation, price mix, productivity and improving its manufacturing efficiency as part of our process of transforming that business, a transformation that was on track before being disrupted by the great recession.
Our results reflect progress in these areas and give us confidence in our ability to achieve our 5% segment operating income margin target. Certainly, we have more actions planned but we are absolutely on the right path.
In Latin America, despite the issues in Venezuela, that reduced our year-over-year results, our team again delivered by nearly offsetting this decrease. Our marketing leading position, our brands, our new products and our distribution networks position us well as Latin America markets continue to advance.
The success and impact of our new product engine was recognized again in China where our recently introduced Goodyear Eagle EfficientGrip tire received Motor Trend magazine's award for Comfort Tire of the Year.
And in Europe, where innovation has been our main stay, we introduced the Goodyear LH2 commercial trailer tire which completes our fuel Mac line up. But it provide us sense of the impact, this product line up delivers, a fleet using fuel matched tires and average long haul operations can realize savings of up to $3000 per truck per year in addition to reducing CO2 emissions by 5200 kilograms per truck per year.
In addition, our high return capital investments targeted that improving costs, capacity and capability are progressing on schedule. Our planned investments of more than a billion dollars in 2010, an increase of more than a third over 2009 demonstrate our commitment to improving our competitiveness and to growing our business.
And our operating cash flow continue to reflect actions, we’ve taken to improve our supply chain and reduce working capital with seasonal growth below historic levels. Our businesses delivered in the second quarter by executing against our strategies and despite the anticipated challenges of second half raw material costs and an unusually uncertain economy, I come out of the quarter energized that we are clearly on the right path.
Relative to the economy, we saw more robust first half 2010 recovery than was anticipated. This was particularly true for North America and Europe. While we see global economies progressing, we remain mindful that consumer spending has not rebounded, unemployment will remain high for an extended period of time and government's response to increased deficits and other sovereign crisis remains undecided and consequently uncertain.
However, we do see tire volumes increasing globally and as a result, see production being added back to our factories. We anticipate truck tire volumes while improving, taking longer to return to pre-recession levels than in our consumer business.
Remember the North American and European truck industry experienced a decrease of about 33% between 2007 and 2009. The improving global economy while certain not to be a straight upward path will provide the environment to fill our factories and grow in both mature markets and emerging markets will allow us to drive our profitable growth strategies by being selective, relative to where we direct our resources of product, of people and of investment.
Executing against our cost plans of capacity reduction and productivity, combined with our investment plans, gives us confidence to navigate through whatever economic environment we are likely to face.
But taking a step back after finishing my first 100 days on the job, I thought it might be helpful for me to provide a perspective of what I have been seeing and give you a view of how I’m thinking about the business.
As you can imagine, I made it a point to visit our business teams around the world as I moved into my new role. I must say this opportunity to interact with these teams is incredibly energizing and is really what gives me confidence in our ability to lead this industry.
Let me share observations with you. I saw an enthusiastic, dedicated and motivated work force with a winning attitude. They’re dedicated to continuous improvement. They’re financially astute, market-back thinkers. They love tires and the tire business and they are solution oriented, not afraid to engage in tough discussions or to make tough decisions and they are dedicated to growing their customers' business.
I saw people lay their focus on demand creation and I saw ingrained in them our philosophy to view the market by segments in terms of growth and profit potential versus simply volume. I saw relentless cash is king focus result in a number of our businesses operating with zero and in some cases even negative working capital.
I saw the strength of our open innovation efforts by our R&D organization. We’ve gone beyond our initial work in computer modeling as an accelerator for physical testing. This development work has now become an enabler of the transformation of our entire development process.
Clearly, this is a competitive advantage as we develop the next generation of tires, which will have expanded capabilities in fuel economy and tread wear and in stopping distance. I saw numerous examples of world class production and engineering processes that separate Goodyear from our competitors.
And I saw examples of our outstanding factory performance, where productivity earns investment and drives not only cost competitiveness but also quality and customer service. I saw significant progress in our investment to produce a new 63-inch radial tire for large mining equipment, which later this year will round out our off the road product portfolio and position us with an industry leading tire in this category.
I saw a greater degree truck tire service efforts in action. Our industry leading fleet service business model is delivering value to our customers that extends well beyond tires. And I’m ear hearing this message repeatedly from fleet operators.
This business model is operating in the Americas, in Europe and will soon be deployed in Asia. Now, when paired with our innovative new products such as the new G399 fuel mileage, our commercial business is favorably positioned as the trucking industry continues to rebound.
I also saw the strength of our commercial truck tire offerings in emerging markets such as Poland and Brazil. In Poland, we went from virtually no presence some ten years ago to a leading position passing all competitors along the way. And in Brazil, our new product line-up has put us in a leading position for radial truck tires.
I saw an enthusiastic and supportive customer base of dealers around the world, who really value our brands, our distribution, our products and our services to help them grow their business, instead of simply selling them tires. And I intended a meeting with more than 80% of our Latin American dealer base, just a few weeks ago in Mexico City. And their enthusiasm for our product offerings, our marketing programs and our growth opportunities in general was tremendous.
They are loyal. They are dedicated and they are committed to growth of our brands and our company. This meeting was an excellent reminder for me that the tire business is also a people business and that relationships truly matter.
And finally, I see evidence that despite the great recession and despite higher fuel costs, people around the world continue to treasure their mobility and they prove it by increasingly driving the vehicles. And as the world's population grows, the vehicle and tire industries will continue to grow both in emerging and mature markets.
And with that growth, will come an evolving demand for technology and for performance that continued evolution of tire performance and consumer expectations is a trend that favors our expertise and will provide ongoing growth opportunities. Now, I add these reflections on our international businesses, the views I had for being the North America team for the previous three years as we developed plans aimed toward our next phase metric of a 5% segment operating income margin.
But we say we continue to be committed to this target, which is a key enabler for the company to reach the global 8% segment operating income metric and position our business for future success. My confidence in achieving the NAT metric is supported by our success over the last four quarters with the business essentially returning to break even performance despite an unprecedented downturn in the industry.
We attribute this success to innovation and impactful new products, thoughtful decisions to improve brand and channel mix, strong work with our dealers to drive our brands in the marketplace, successful management of price and mix and our cost reduction initiatives.
Certainly, we still have many challenges, most specifically the raw material increases in a still somewhat uncertain economy but we are managing everything in our control extremely well to keep us on the path to our profitability objective.
Now, if you recall, before the bottom fell out of our global economy, we had already achieve our goal of two and a half times debt to EBIDTA and were within reach of our 8% goal and 5% NAT next stage metric goal. We are now back on that path.
So what does this path look like? Our current path in North America includes the benefit of continuing moderate industry recovery, offsetting raw material cost increases through price mix improvements over time, driving an improved cost structure including U.S. building and contract implementation, a significant footprint action although no final decisions have been made at this time and reduced pension expense as we fund plans and as active values increase.
Our ability to achieve this goal remains dependent on the pace and consistency of economic recovery in North America, the timing of which quite frankly is a question currently on almost everyone’s mind. We certainly have a timetable in mind and are confident in our plans to get there.
However, today's environment makes predicting a timetable quite difficult. I believe that we are on the right path, supported by a long-proven track record of execution in areas within our control.
So as you can tell, I'm excited about our industry, our company and our future opportunities and as positive as I’m about the things I saw, I also see additional opportunities for improvement. The trends I see support the investments we are making and support our ability to differentiate ourselves in the marketplace.
The global growth opportunities I see have perhaps never been better. Now, looking ahead, my near-term focus remains on the areas, I discussed last quarter, offsetting escalating raw material costs with price mix and material cost reduction and substitution programs.
Our track record here certainly speaks for itself. Improving manufacturing efficiency through changing how we work in our factories and by getting increased operating leverage out of our existing equipment and building a world class advanced supply chain that not only efficiently makes and delivers the right tire to our customers but let's us do so with lower investment and inventory.
We’re seeing our efforts already produce results and our growing North America truck business, where we are achieving higher levels of service with significantly lower levels of inventory.
Now, understanding that these areas will take time to fully develop and meet our ultimate expectations, we improved in each area so far this year and expect to continue to do so over the second half and into 2011.
I see our progress in these areas as necessary to address near-term headwinds and a volatile economy but ultimately execution against these imperatives is required for us to take advantage of the growth opportunities in China, Latin America and Eastern Europe.
Now, these are markets where we have leading positions, where we have demonstrated capability and where we have identified segments with profitable growth potential.
Now, before I turn the call over to Darren, what I conclude following my first 100 days is that we are successfully executing our strategies of improved productivity in our manufacturing plants, increased capabilities and efficiency in our supply chain, success with innovative branded products in growth segments and regions around the world, continued progress in reducing costs and increasing our cash position and top line growth through all customers and channels.
These are the foundations of a sustainable business model that will give us the ability to lead this industry and to reach our next stage metrics. Now, I’m going to turn the call over to Darren.

headline: Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks Rich. There are four significant things, you see reflected in our second quarter results. These things include first success in our work to drive price mix within our replacement business. While consumer replacement volume was up only modestly, the
componenttext:
Thanks Rich. There are four significant things, you see reflected in our second quarter results. These things include first success in our work to drive price mix within our replacement business. While consumer replacement volume was up only modestly, the consumer replacement business was the big driver of improved earnings. As we successfully executed price increases and continued to shift mix from private label to branded products.
Second, volume growth was weighted toward OE. With 3.2 million of our 3.9 million increase in units coming in the OE segment, this reflects increased OE production that we are contractually required to supply. This reduced our opportunity to grow in their replacement business and cut our price mix as we were unable to fully reflect raw material cost increases in our early pricing.
Third, strong performance in our commercial business, taking advantage of recovering markets while also growing our share in many geographies. One particular success that means a lot to our team. It’s that we now have achieved the number one position in radial truck tires in Brazil. Passing a key competitor as truck believes continue to move from bias to radial truck tires.
And fourth, outstanding way to reduce costs and recover the fixed cost that created a significant drag on our results over the last two years. Notwithstanding our strong top line performance, we remain completely committed to addressing our cost structure. We expect these themes will continue to be factors as we move into the second half.
Looking at the income statement, our unit sales increased by 10% and revenue increased 15% in Q2, reflecting improvement in global tire demand in both consumer and commercial markets as well as improved price mix.
Each business unit exceeded 2009 unit sales and revenues and price mix more than offset increased raw material costs. Margins, segment operating income and net income all increased versus the prior year.
SHG increased to $670 million from $614 million last year, driven by three factors. First, the recent adverse court ruling that Rich mentioned which impacted SHG and North America by about $20 million. Second, increased advertising to support our strong brands and to drive emerging markets growth. And third compensation accruals.
Note that, second quarter after tax results in both periods were impacted by certain significant items. The appendix includes a summary of these items for 2010 and 2009. Second operating income in the quarter increased 195 million. This increase reflected higher volume as well as the benefit of lower unabsorbed fixed costs compared with a year ago.
This continues the trend that we’ve seen in the prior two quarters. Given production levels in Q1 which were up nearly 6 million units from previous year, the amount of unabsorbed fixed costs in Q2 results after a one quarter Lag was 71 million lower than a year ago or about $12 per tire consistent with our guidance.
Price mix of $121 million more than offset raw material cost increases of $89 million or 6% in the quarter. The majority of raw material cost increases in the quarter affected our Asian Pacific and Latin America businesses which tend to see raw material cost increases hit more quickly in Europe and North America.
North America and Europe will see more of the increases starting in Q3. I fully argue [ph], we executed 35 million of raw material cost savings actions in the quarter reducing the net raw material cost increase to $54 million.
Including these savings, our cost reduction plan generated benefit of $133 million during the quarter. Cost savings actions provided significant net benefits as inflation was about $60 million in the quarter.
As we discussed in our first quarter call, savings this year will be front-end loaded, given the first half carrier the benefits from significant headcount reductions and other actions taken during the great recession, which made up a significant portion of our first half cost savings.
Savings in the second half will show less change versus last year as head count is stabilized, reflecting a ramp up in production to support market recovery. As anticipated pension expense began to decline in our North American business in the second quarter after increasing in Q1.
Currency hurt our international earnings, primarily due to the effect of the devaluation in Venezuela and the weaker Euro versus U.S. dollar. Given the continuing weakness of the Euro, which fell over 8% versus last year to an average of 126 in the second quarter. We expect foreign currency pressures to continue in the second half.
Last year’s average Euro exchange rate in Q3 was a $1.43 and in Q4, it was $1.47. If Q2 rates were to continue, the negative impact of currency translations in the remaining quarters would be higher than the impact we saw in Q2.
What is now broken out in the chart, Venezuela continued to negatively impact results. The Q2 year-over-year impact was $32 million, which was somewhat worse than our expectations primarily reflecting lower volumes.
Let me take you on situation in Venezuela as I discussed the business unit results. As we turn now to the balance sheet, our efforts to manage working capital continue to be effective, even as higher raw material costs and improved demand put pressure on receivables and inventory.
Working capital was up about a $100 million versus the end of March, less than what we would typically expect. Q2 and Q3 typically reflect cash usage for increased working capital ahead of cash inflows in Q4. The cash use would have been far more without the significant benefits we’re experiencing from supply chain improvements that we’ve made over the last two years.
We ended the quarter with cash liquidity of $4.2 billion, which is down about a $100 million from Q1 reflecting the seasonal growth in working capital.
Turning to the segment results, North America reported segment operating income was $16 million in the quarter, which compares to a loss of $91 million in the 2009 period. The 2010 results reflects sales of more than 2 billion and volume of 16.6 million units, a nearly 21% increase in sales or a 13% increase in unit volume.
The North American results were supported by strong industry recovery versus a challenging 2009 environment. Consumer replacement industry volume increased by 5% in Q2 while the consumer OE industry was 70% higher. They are mainly reflecting little production a year ago giving Chrysler and GM shutdowns during the government supported restructurings.
Commercial trucking street conditions also improved with the replacement industry increasing by 22% on higher freight tonnage. We see increased tonnage being driven by improving economic activity and inventory restocking across sectors.
The commercial OE industry grew 42% as fleets begin to address the need for replacement of aging vehicles. So we see improving industry conditions in all NAT core businesses.
As the industry continued to recover, our North American business continues to drive branded share gains, our consumer replacement business. Our decision to eliminate two remaining private label brands and replace them with the broad availability of the Kelly brand has been affective and increasing our branded share and improving our product mix this year.
Our overall replacement share, however, was down slightly impacted by two factors. First, increased OE demand which limited product availability in our replacement business. And second, private label volume, we eliminated in line with our Kelly brand strategy.
Revenue per tire as well as replacement business in North America increased about 4% versus 2009, reflecting enhanced priced increases. Revenue per tire gains were offset partially by a higher mix of lower revenue consumer of elite tires driven by the recovery in elite production. Including this impact, overall revenue per tire grew by 1%.
North American earnings improved our higher sales volumes and the benefit of fixed cost recovery on higher production. While strong priced mixed performance also drove earnings higher as raw materials were essentially flat.
The recently announced price increase up to 6% in consumer and up to 8% in commercial will be fully realized beginning in Q3, along with the benefit of nine new products launched in Q2. Lower pension cost and net productivity improvements in our plants also improved our results.
Europe, Middle East and Africa reported segment operating income of $73 million in the quarter, which compares to a loss of 15 million in the 2009 period. The 2010 results reflect sales of about 1.5 billion and volume of 16.8 million units, a 4.5% increase in seals on a 6% increase in unit volume.
Industry volumes rose in Europe, Middle East and Africa as well. The consumer replacement tire market increased 11% year-over-year (inaudible) for early demand for winter tires as trade inventories were very low after a strong 2009, 2010 winter season.
The consumer OE industry increased 8% which was more than we expected. The commercial replacement market grew by 19%. The commercial OE market rebounded partially driven by exports with Q2 77% higher than a year ago with all of these implemented factory shutdowns.
EMEA sales growth reflected an improving economy and strong early winter tire market which was up 56% compared to a year ago, coupled with price increases to offset higher raw material costs. Strong execution by our team in Eastern Europe resulted in a 10% volume increase versus Q2 of ' 09.
We continued to gain market share in Q2 in both consumer and truck in Eastern Europe, Middle East and Africa. Our sales in EMEA also reflected determination of our agreement to distribute certain tires produced by (inaudible) which represented about 1.8 million units in full year 2009.
The stronger U.S. dollar versus a year ago negatively impacted net sales for the quarter by 83 million. EMEA segment operating income improved to 88 million driven by higher volume, increased price mix of 23 million, which more than offset raw material increases of 3 million as well as higher factory utilization levels which resulted in the benefit of 36 million from lower unobserved fixed costs.
In Latin America, we reported segment operating of 66 million on sales revenue of 529 million, which represents a revenue increase of 21% on a 13% increase in unit volume versus the prior year. Segment operating incomes was down from last year. To keep the very perspective; however, the $7 million reduction in segment operating income compared to a year ago in Latin America reflected two offsetting forces.
Our business in Brazil and other countries outside Venezuela increased earnings by $25 million. Unfortunately, this improvement was more than offset by a decrease in earnings in Venezuela, 32 million which I will discuss further in a moment.
Stronger sales reflect the ongoing economic recovery in most of the region, especially in Brazil where the latest GDP statistics showed almost 9% growth for the first quarter, while industrial production continues to show strength. Excluding Venezuela, the replacement growth is been robust with consumer and commercial industry volumes, increasing more than 15% versus Q2 last year.
The recovery in OE markets has been even stronger. Market share in both consumer and commercial replacement businesses were strong in the quarter, reflecting the benefits of a strong new product lineup. This product line will be further enhanced with the launch of DuraPlus with Fuel Max Technology in the second half.
Price mix benefits more than offset higher raw material cost in the quarter, while also helping address the currency devaluation in Venezuela. These actions drove a 9% increase in revenue per tire versus the prior year.
Coming back to the situation in Venezuela, the impact on segment operating income of the devaluation and economic weakness in Q2 was $32 million, raising the impact in the first half to $60 million versus the prior year. The adverse full year impact may now exceed our prior guidance of up to $75 million versus last year. We continued negative impact in Q3. The comparable becomes easier starting in Q4. This will take our full earnings in Venezuela back to levels consistent with 2008, before the significant peak we saw in the Venezuela market in 2009, just before the devaluation.
The higher than expected Q2 impact reflects lower sales volume as consumers in Venezuela have started to pull back, operational disruptions for lack of supplies and high absenteeism and difficulties importing raw materials and finished goods. We remain confident however, with some second half improvement. Given, we’ve already secured the approval necessary for import licenses required for second half operations.
We continue to take actions to increase local production of truck tires. And we are working to offset the impact of increased costs. While this remains a difficult situation, our team is taking steps to return our business there to higher levels of profitability over time.
Our Asia Pacific business fueled by strong market demand in China and India, reported record second quarter segment operating income. Successful price/mix actions combined with a volume increase in excess of 9% and ineffective cost controls, more than offset raw material cost increases.
The team continues to leverage strong market growth in key segments. In China, sales continue to reflect strong economic growth, product innovation and improvement in our distribution capabilities. In Q2, Goodyear reported its highest ever consumer replacement volume in the Chinese market. In India, we also achieved record sales in consumer replacement. In Thailand, Goodyear was named the most trusted brand for the second year in a row. And our OTR and aviation businesses showed continued strength, driven by demand for raw materials and air transportation in both China and India. Our business in Australia has recovered significantly, leveraging low cost supply and strong distribution channels as markets recover.
The opportunities in Asian markets remain significant, driven by continued OE demand and rapidly growing replacement market, especially in China and India. In response, we are continuing to enhance our product lineup. We will launch the Eagle EfficientGrip and the Assurance Fuel Max Tires in Asia in the second half of this year. Both of these tires are already receiving third party accolades, building our brand awareness.
As part of our plan to take advantage of growth opportunities in these markets, we continue to make progress on the relocation and expansion of our Dalian, China factory which once operational will help us continue our growth in China. In addition, we also continued to reduce our cost structure in the region, with the announced closure of our factory in Taiwan. So across all our business units, you saw evidence of successful execution of our strategies, improving price mix despite the difficulty of increased OE mix and strong performance in our commercial business. And of course, continued cost improvements.
Turning to our outlook for the remainder of the year, we have updated our views including our expectations for industry volumes and raw materials. Looking at industry volumes, we provided updated expectations for full year industry growth in North America and Europe on slide 21.
As you can see, we continue to expect growth in the key market segments for North America and Europe, have increased our expectation somewhat, particularly in commercial truck. Overall, given volumes were up significantly in the second half of 2009, year-over-year industry comparisons for Q3 and Q4 on a percentage basis will be less.
Looking at raw materials, while recent moderation of rubber prices have held reduced the impact of raw material cost somewhat. The benefit would be concentrated in Q4. We expect the peak year-over-year increase will occur in the third quarter. Raw materials are expected to increase 30% to 35% Q3 versus the prior year and we expect Q4 to increase about 30%.
From modeling purposes, we now expect 2010 interest expense to be in the range of $325 to $350 million as interest rates remain at historically low levels. The outlook for tax expense and CapEx remain unchanged from the levels provided in the first quarter call, recognizing, this implies both CapEx will increase in the second half compared with the first six months.
We are very pleased with the continued improvements we had in the first half of the year. We remain very positive regarding the long-term prospects for our business. Global growth and continued high demand, for higher technology tires provide significant opportunity for Goodyear. This will allow us to continue to improve our operating results, leveraging a richer mix of products, a shift to a lower cost manufacturing footprint, growth in emerging markets and reduction in legacy cost to deliver on our next stage metrics.
Now, we will open up the call for Q&A.

headline: Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you. (Operator Instructions) Your first question comes from the line of Rod Lache with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Thank you. (Operator Instructions) Your first question comes from the line of Rod Lache with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning, Rod.
componenttext: Good morning, Rod.

headline: Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everybody. I had a couple of questions. First of all, there are a whole bunch of reasons why your North America replacement volume has been just a little bit less than the overall market. And I was wondering, when you expect to start cycling
componenttext: Good morning, everybody. I had a couple of questions. First of all, there are a whole bunch of reasons why your North America replacement volume has been just a little bit less than the overall market. And I was wondering, when you expect to start cycling through some of those things, like the Kelly brand discontinuation. Is there a point when you think that Goodyear will start to track in line with and better than the overall industry in North American replacements specifically?

headline: Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Rod, let me answer that, but to be clear, we haven't discontinued Kelly. We actually have taken it from a handful of dealers, if you will and taken it nationally to all our dealers. In fact it is going very well. We discontinued the Remington and the Repu
componenttext:
Rod, let me answer that, but to be clear, we haven't discontinued Kelly. We actually have taken it from a handful of dealers, if you will and taken it nationally to all our dealers. In fact it is going very well. We discontinued the Remington and the Republic brands, just for clarity. That’s okay.
But just to your question, I think it’s a good one because as we look at the industry, our North America replacement volumes was slightly up, but certainly the industry was up a bit more. And if you look at it, what it reflects to us is we look at the quarter, is increased brand share in Goodyear and in the Kelly brand. Certainly, we had success in broadening the distribution of our Kelly brand. We had significant share increase there.
And that was offset by the elimination, again, of those two Remington and Republic brands, getting out of those lower end businesses, again, is a conscious decision to mix-up our North America business. And also it was offset by our stronger OE volumes. There were up significantly. Industry was up about 70% and that required us to reallocate production away from our mixed up higher end replacement, to meet some of those as you know contractual commitments that we have.
So as we look out, I would say we are very confident and what we have in terms of products or product lineup. The distribution, our supply chain activities, we think this will allow us to maintain and improve that share of our brands going forward. In terms of an exact time, it’s harder to say but as I think about it over the horizon, I'm not overly concerned that we can't get that share back.

headline: Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. And on page 21 where you provide the industry outlook, it looks like the majority of the North America consumer replacement volume growth could really be attributable to the first half. Are you expecting some moderation there and can you also give u
componenttext: Okay. And on page 21 where you provide the industry outlook, it looks like the majority of the North America consumer replacement volume growth could really be attributable to the first half. Are you expecting some moderation there and can you also give us some color on what your production levels were quite relative to what the shipments were, were you operating at a higher level or lower level than where shipments were?

headline: Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: So, I’ll start and I’ll tell you, in terms of how we look at the second half. I think, we still feel very good where the market is going in the second half. What you see in terms of first half and second half, just remember, second half of 2009 we had
componenttext: So, I’ll start and I’ll tell you, in terms of how we look at the second half. I think, we still feel very good where the market is going in the second half. What you see in terms of first half and second half, just remember, second half of 2009 we had the impact of the ITC ruling, the 421 ruling which had strong volumes last year and we also had more than of OE phenomenon but certainly Cash for Clunkers as well. So when you look year-over-year second half, the second half, I would you, it’s more of a comp issue than any kind of trend issue in the marketplace. In terms of the production levels, I’ll let Darren address that.

headline: Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yeah. So, Rod, when you’ll see and you’ll have a chance to take a look at the appendix as we have provided some information there as we’ve done in the past. But, Q2 production levels were up about 6.7 million units versus last year. So where that br
componenttext:
Yeah. So, Rod, when you’ll see and you’ll have a chance to take a look at the appendix as we have provided some information there as we’ve done in the past. But, Q2 production levels were up about 6.7 million units versus last year. So where that brings us to is just under 43 million units of production versus a capacity of about 50 million a quarter.
That, I mean, it obviously reflects higher sales as well as non-recurrence of the inventory reductions we went through a year ago. So if we build a little under 43 million units, you see sales are about 44 million units. And we talked about the fact that, that last year we had about 10 million units that we brought in or 2.5 a quarter from third parties.
So, I think, take that assume, the 2.5 or 3 from third parties, what you’re going to conclude is we did build those inventory back during the quarter, which is there, to help us meet market demands, to deal with seasonality and hopefully address the market share question you asked earlier.
So production in Q2 is about 43 million units. Obviously, we’ve got a couple of plants, significant plants that are still running below capacity given the fact that we’ve got footprint actions plant including the plant that we’ve announced in plant in Amiens, France. But, yeah, does that, hopefully that gets your question.

headline: Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yeah. And just lastly, you typically see seasonally stronger earnings in the back half for your company than the first half and I’m wondering whether you’re kind of looking at a different pattern this year, just given the FX headwind and the cost savi
componenttext: Yeah. And just lastly, you typically see seasonally stronger earnings in the back half for your company than the first half and I’m wondering whether you’re kind of looking at a different pattern this year, just given the FX headwind and the cost savings comments and raw material comments you made in your prepared remarks?

headline: Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yeah. So, Rod, I think, the others, there are clearly things that we expect to continue to make progress on, so I think, I’d say that, first and foremost, we see continued momentum in products, continued momentum in driving improved mix to the business,
componenttext:
Yeah. So, Rod, I think, the others, there are clearly things that we expect to continue to make progress on, so I think, I’d say that, first and foremost, we see continued momentum in products, continued momentum in driving improved mix to the business, continued momentum in our cost savings programs. But, absolute confidence there but you’re right to point that currency in the second half really, particularly on year-over-year basis, more headwind than we saw in the first half.
First half we had some benefit of cost savings from other restructuring that we did during the great recession. And we’ve now gotten through a full year benefits of those. So there’s no incremental benefit from those restructuring as we look forward because they were already in the second half last year. The volume comps obviously tougher and we’ve got increased raw materials sequentially, as raw materials continue to roll through our inventories and costs of goods sold. So it’s appropriate to point the fact, that those are challenges that we in the second half.

We’re focusing on those parts of the market where we can win focusing on brand, focusing on mix and that’s really weighs a much more important level for us than just pure volume.

It seems even if you slow down a costs to cope up, maybe you achieve upwards half of that this year?

headline: Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, Itay, I would tell you that, we are tracking very well. I’ll let Darren walk you through some of the particulars. But as we look forward, our focus is not only on mixing up and doing it with the right brands or channels, but cost is, has been and
componenttext: Well, Itay, I would tell you that, we are tracking very well. I’ll let Darren walk you through some of the particulars. But as we look forward, our focus is not only on mixing up and doing it with the right brands or channels, but cost is, has been and will remain a priority for Goodyear as we move forward. So I feel very confident and you should feel - hear from us very confident that we are tracking towards that and we’re going to continue to focus on it and our goal is do it even fast than where as we have said. But Darren maybe go through bit of the details.

headline: Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yeah. Itay, obviously, we are happy with our progress for the first half. So, we’ve got 200 - over $280 million in cost savings through the first half from initiatives around the company. We had improved manufacturing efficiency. We’ve gotten some imp
componenttext:
Yeah. Itay, obviously, we are happy with our progress for the first half. So, we’ve got 200 - over $280 million in cost savings through the first half from initiatives around the company. We had improved manufacturing efficiency. We’ve gotten some improvements from sourcing products in low cost countries. We’ve done a good job and got some benefit of SAG restructuring. And, we’ve taken actions to reduce transportation costs and you’ll see highlighted in the materials.
But that we had a cost savings in the raw material category for raw material substitution and construction changes we’ve been able to make to take way down in tires, the total $35 million just for the second quarter. So with raw materials going up, a lot more focus of our engineers has been going into how do we reduce the amount of material and type of the cost, the type of material in the tires. So we feel very good about the costs saving $280 for the first half.
But I will bring you back to the fact that, we cut about 5500 associates out of - off of our payrolls during the mid 2008 to mid 2009 timeframe and we got the full benefit of that in the first half and that was a significant part of the $280 million. So without that impact of the headcount reduction obviously the run rate of $280 is a lot different number.
We remain - my point at this stage is that we remain committed to our prior guidance of achieving a billion dollars over three years. Keeping ourselves on pace to offset general inflation and look for opportunities to make improvement beyond that. And we’ve got prudent track record of driving those costs reductions and we are going to stay focused on it. So, that's how we’d answer the question at this point. But I think, it is important to take into account what was going on with the restructuring savings in the first half.

headline: Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: That’s help. Thanks. And maybe a follow-up cash flow question. It looks like some of your interest expense guidance. You do expect a pretty material bump in interest expense in the second half of the year. But then I think about the seasonal cash flow y
componenttext: That’s help. Thanks. And maybe a follow-up cash flow question. It looks like some of your interest expense guidance. Just help me kind of think about why interest would drop maybe 30-plus million and maybe net debt should be coming down in the second half?

componenttextpreview: I think there are a couple of things here. I think first of all we do have - there continues to be some market expectations for variable rates going up and we don’t predict interest rates but we do look at what the forward curve looks like, in estimatin
componenttext:
I think there are a couple of things here. I think first of all we do have - there continues to be some market expectations for variable rates going up and we don’t predict interest rates but we do look at what the forward curve looks like, in estimating our variable interest expense.
Second point here is that our peak working capital in many cases has been in the third quarter and right now we’ve it's been building and we’ve done a good job constraining it, but this does take into account the fact that the average debt balance, in the second half we’re expecting to be higher than the average debt balance in the first half.

headline: Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Commercial truck. I would say that inventories are still pretty good out in the channel in the sense that people are still buying. No one was long on inventory coming out of 2009. The channel was low, it starting to restock a little bit. So we see an oppo
componenttext:
Commercial truck. I would say that inventories are still pretty good out in the channel in the sense that people are still buying. No one was long on inventory coming out of 2009. The channel was low, it starting to restock a little bit. So we see an opportunity to sell more tires. I mean, as we look at it, we see that the commercial recovery is happening in each of our businesses and you notice we increased the outlook both in America and European replacement in OE markets.
And again, we saw, as you know, a significant commercial drop from - in our business from 17 million units in '07 down to about 12 million in '09, and when we look at our second quarter, we’re kind of run on an annualized rate now call it 14 million units.
So as the market recovers, we see our sales increasing, we see our factory utilization improving and we’re building what we sell this year versus cutting inventories, so, we have an uncertain economy out there as you know as well. But ultimately for right now we are seeing the recovering coming and we are selling more tires and it’s not being impacted by any adverse inventory situation in the channel.

headline: Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. I wanted to go back to, I think, it was Darren's comment about, you guys being hurt on the mix front because of a contractual increase in consumer OE demand. I'm just curious, I mean, I know there is quarter-to-quarter issues on that. But just when
componenttext:
Okay. I wanted to go back to, I think, it was Darren's comment about, you guys being hurt on the mix front because of a contractual increase in consumer OE demand. I'm just curious, I mean, I know there is quarter-to-quarter issues on that. But just when you step back and look over the next three years.
I think most people would argue that the rate of growth in North American auto production from today's starting point for consumer OE is probably going to be greater than the kind of potential rebound that could happen on consumer replacement. And so what are the implications for your business on that? I mean, that would just seem to suggest that mix would only get worse for you guys, because more and more your consumer high value added tire capacity would be directed into OE as a percentage of total?

headline: Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yeah. Himanshu, it’s a good question and I’ll tell you how we think about it. As we’ve looked at our business over the course of the last few years, what you’ve seen is a lot of time spent on getting our mix right. And if we go back, maybe more fu
componenttext:
Yeah. Himanshu, it’s a good question and I’ll tell you how we think about it. As we’ve looked at our business over the course of the last few years, what you’ve seen is a lot of time spent on getting our mix right. And if we go back, maybe more further than is relevant to the question but to make a point, we had a very high share of OE and we had a lot of fitments that we didn't like. And systemically, we have worked that down over a - over call it five, six, seven-year period to get to a point where we like our mix much better today in OE than we did back then.
And I would tell that that’s a process that will continue to go through. We have been very, very discipline on our selectivity of what fitments we take and what fitments we don’t and that’s a process that we will continue. We still like the OE business but we’ve got to make decisions that make sense for Goodyear on an MVP basis meaning that we are going to put a tire on a new car that we have opportunities to put Goodyear tires at the first, second and even third replacement as we look at it. If we can't do that, we’ll going to make decisions appropriately.
So as you think about it going out, as you think about the market increasing, it’s not sort of a one to one correlation that OE goes up and replacement constraint. We will continue to be selective in OE and some of that capacity will move into the higher margin replacement market and that's how we see the business going forward. So I don't want to have you think that the situation we saw in the second quarter is going to be indicative of two and three years out.

headline: Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then two last questions on just the demand situation, I guess, plus about Goodyear but maybe just the overall industry. First on Latin America and then on North America, in Latin America there was sequential weakening in Q2 divisional profits ev
componenttext: Okay. And then two last questions on just the demand situation, I guess, plus about Goodyear but maybe just the overall industry. First on Latin America and then on North America, in Latin America there was sequential weakening in Q2 divisional profits even though volumes look like they were slightly up. Was that all Venezuela sequentially weakening in terms of underlying demand and if that is the case, can you just give us a sense on what’s actually happening there sequentially, has the consumer at least stabilized now or is there, are we still in a phase of sequential deterioration there?

headline: Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, Himanshu, I think, Venezuela obviously was the driver in the year-over-year decrease, Darren made reference for those in his comments. So Darren, maybe just elaborate on that a bit more?
componenttext: Well, Himanshu, I think, Venezuela obviously was the driver in the year-over-year decrease, Darren made reference for those in his comments. So Darren, maybe just elaborate on that a bit more?

headline: Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yeah. Himanshu, I think, when you look at this sequentially, what we’re looking at is, continued issue in Venezuela but I would not make, yeah, I wouldn't read into it that Venezuela was down from Q1 to Q2. The Q1 was our highest level of disruption as
componenttext:
Yeah. Himanshu, I think, when you look at this sequentially, what we’re looking at is, continued issue in Venezuela but I would not make, yeah, I wouldn't read into it that Venezuela was down from Q1 to Q2. The Q1 was our highest level of disruption as we went through a period where the government was adjusting rules and regulations for the new exchange regime. So second quarter was, maybe slight normalization but certainly not the kind of benefit that we expected to get. So I think, second quarter was worse than we would have anticipated.
The sequential changes in Latin America, there are a number of factors here, but there were some cost related issues there that we went through in the second quarter. We had some labor negotiations that had some cost implications for us and there are some things and you’ll notice that in the list of significant items, there is one $3 million item that related to the settlement of a review of import taxes that we went through there and that hurt in the quarter as well. So couple cost related issues was really the driver in the terms of the sequential decline. Venezuela is right now the big variable for us in Latin America. And now, year-to-date we’re down 60 million versus 2009 in Venezuela and we’ve changed our, the way we have talked about the full year impact and previously we had said 50 to 75 million and now we are saying it could 75 million or a little bit more which takes us back to essentially what we were earning in Venezuela in 2008.
So, 2009 was very much a peak earning period in Venezuela, 2010 is coming back down to levels that we had seen prior to 2009, prior to that peak. So the good news is those markets are stabilizing. And we’ve already secured - some of the problem that we had there has been importing raw materials and importing finished goods particularly truck tires or that market. We’ve already secured the necessary import license that we need for the second half. So we’ve gotten the approvals we need to get import licenses for Q3 and Q4, so that’s a good thing. Yeah, we are in the process of increasing our local production of truck tires so we don't have the concern about supply for that market. And there had been a lot of actions taken to deal with the increased cost that we’d experienced there. So it remains a difficult situation. We see improvement coming in the second half and improvement coming overtime in Venezuela. And the rest of Latin America we that - we see the business doing very well, so we had a few unique cost items in the second quarter, but the Latin American business model outside Venezuela continues to operate very well, the consumer and commercial businesses in Brazil and other markets around Latin America very strong and our teams are absolutely performing there.

headline: Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay.
componenttext: Okay.

headline: Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I just want to add one thing just to in a general sense, because when we look at our earnings in Latin America Darren, walk you through what we’re seeing but remember disruption in Latin America happen, I have always said that some disruption was going
componenttext: I just want to add one thing just to in a general sense, because when we look at our earnings in Latin America Darren, walk you through what we’re seeing but remember disruption in Latin America happen, I have always said that some disruption was going to come here and it happened to Venezuela right now. It really, in my mind you have to bifurcate both what happens when we have a one-off disruptions like Venezuela to our core business in Latin America our team's ability to execute our core business in terms of product, our product line has been essentially revamped, our distribution, our customers, our people down there. Our core business model will continue to move forward and Venezuela just happens to be one of a historical set of disruptions, we will manage through and we’ll drive that business forward.

headline: Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: There are two additional points I would make John, one a lot of the revenue volatile in the chemical business is related to price indexing of the raw materials that go into the chemical business. So while you see a lot of volatility on the revenue line, i
componenttext: There are two additional points I would make John, one a lot of the revenue volatile in the chemical business is related to price indexing of the raw materials that go into the chemical business. So while you see a lot of volatility on the revenue line, if doesn't necessarily translate through to earnings, it’s effectively pass - us passing through the cost of fire inputs to our chemical customers under contract. Since the volatility in revenue doesn’t translate to volatility in earnings, that the first point. The second point is the first half, we did see in North America some benefit to earnings as a result of our - what we could refer to as our other tire related businesses which include chemical and includes retail, it includes our wind put commercial truck tire businesses and we did get some benefit there. As the first half of last year was very weak, the first half of this year was much stronger. As we go forward, that's not going to be - it is not going to be a continued year-over-year benefit from those businesses because they caught up to more normalized levels right now. So those are the points, the other points I make - the other tire related business in the chemical sales.

headline: Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Darren, can address this a bit further but I will tell you, as we look at our supply chain efforts, we’ve been demonstrating particularly as I mentioned in certain of our businesses of driving our growth in our businesses with equal or lower inventories
componenttext: Darren, can address this a bit further but I will tell you, as we look at our supply chain efforts, we’ve been demonstrating particularly as I mentioned in certain of our businesses of driving our growth in our businesses with equal or lower inventories that we saw at low points over the course of the past few years. Our truck business now is operating with about half the inventory it had before in terms of units. And that's one of the things we are looking at in terms of working capital. We’re seeing the advantage supply chain initiative turning up in our inventory and consequently turning up in benefits and cash flow. Now the working capital and cash flow store certainly more complex on that, so Darren, you may want to comment a bit further on how we’re thinking about full year cash flow in year-over-year.

headline: Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And, I think we feel good about where the cash flow is. But there are - you recognized that there are some significant differences between what we saw in 2009 and what we see and expect in 2010. And some of that is going to be more prevalent in the first
componenttext: And, I think we feel good about where the cash flow is. But there are - you recognized that there are some significant differences between what we saw in 2009 and what we see and expect in 2010. And some of that is going to be more prevalent in the first half than it was in the second half and that includes higher capital expenditures, increasing from about 750 million last year to our guidance at a billion, to a billion 1 for 2010. Through the first half, we saw essentially the same level as last year, so the increase is coming from the second half. Working capital, we said this year, we were expecting working capital to increase 200 million and what you’ve seen through the first half would have been less working capital build than you might have expected, which says, there is still the view that as we have raw materials continue to increase and as we continue to adjust our inventories to the higher growth rate that we’ve seen in the industry there still be some cash that we use in the second half. So I think, you’re looking at it the right way, we’re absolutely with the performance that we put in, in the supply chain and I think that will permanently changed amount of working capital require to run our business, but the cash flow outlook for this year, I think there are still some items that you will see coming in the second half.
