headline: Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone, and welcome to Goodyear's third quarter conference call. With me today are Rich Kramer, President and CEO; and Darren Wells, Executive Vice President and CFO.Before we get started, there are a few items I would like to cover. To
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone, and welcome to Goodyear's third quarter conference call. With me today are Rich Kramer, President and CEO; and Darren Wells, Executive Vice President and CFO.
Before we get started, there are a few items I would like to cover. To begin, the webcast of this morning’s discussion and the supporting slide presentation can be found on our website, at investor.goodyear.com. A replay of this call will be accessible later today. Replay instructions were included in our earnings release issued earlier this morning. The last item, we plan to file our 10-Q later today.
If I can now direct your attention to the Safe Harbor statement on Slide 2 of the presentation. Our discussion this morning may contain forward-looking statements based on our current expectations and assumptions that are subject to risks and uncertainties that can cause actual results to differ materially.
These risks and uncertainties are outlined in Goodyear’s filings with the SEC and in the news release we issued this morning. The company disclaims any intention or obligation to update or revise any forward-looking statements whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise.
Turning now to the agenda. On today’s call, Rich will provide a business review. After Rich’s remarks, Darren will discuss the financial results and outlook before opening the call to your questions.
That finishes my comments and I'll now turn the call over to Rich.

headline: Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Pat, and good morning, everyone. We appreciate you being with us today. Now before I talk about Goodyear's third quarter results, which I would say I'm very pleased with overall, I first want to sure with you some observations about the tire indus
componenttext:
Thanks, Pat, and good morning, everyone. We appreciate you being with us today. Now before I talk about Goodyear's third quarter results, which I would say I'm very pleased with overall, I first want to sure with you some observations about the tire industry and where we are in a recovery. 
And while cautious, certainly feel much better about what we have recently been seeing in the economy and in our industry, especially in the context of what our forward-looking views were 2 years ago when we saw volumes drop by almost 20%.
We're seeing the associated benefits of economic growth as global markets begin to recover. Our industry and the industry in general is on an upward tick. We're seeing evidence of investments in essentially every region of the globe and tire unit volumes, even in truck, are trending back to higher levels at a faster pace than anyone had anticipated. And I note that we've raised our industry outlook throughout the year in Europe and North America and in emerging markets, particularly Brazil and China, industry volumes are continuing to grow and have already exceeded volume levels reached before the great recession.
So what does all this mean for Goodyear? While demand for our products is strong, volumes are growing on a path to pre-recession levels in our mix strategies exceeding. Our planned capacity utilization is improving, and we have benefited from the ability to offer a strong value proposition with our premium award winning products. 
The bottom line is that as we look to the future, we feel good about the direction of the tire industry, and we feel even better about the direction and the company. If I think specifically about our third quarter performance with the industry recovery as a backdrop, it was a very good operational quarter for us. We made progress in every one of our areas of significant focus. Together, this success has provided me a level of confidence that our third quarter performance is another positive step toward our next stage metrics.
As we specifically look at some of the Q3 highlights, our unit sales continued to grow reflecting not only the industry growth but also share gains in targeted markets driven by demand for our premium products. Our revenue is up 13% or a couple of points higher if you exclude the adverse impact of currency. The growth reflects higher unit volumes and increased revenue per tire with our North America business leading the way with a 17% growth.
Our revenue per tire globally increased by 8% versus a year ago reflecting our pricing actions, as well as a continuation of our planned shift in mix towards higher margin segments. Our price/mix overall totaled more than $250 million for the quarter, an 8% increase in commercial truck tires volumes globally. We had higher levels of factory utilization and higher productivity flowing to the bottom line. And our year-to-date cost savings now total approximately $350 million.
Segment operating income in the quarter was $234 million, and while this is down from last year it is higher than the second quarter, in part reflecting our success and offsetting most of the sequentially significantly higher raw materials of $157 million with strong pricing mix. Also in the quarter, we continued to improve our balance sheet, completing $1 billion debt issuance and redemption that extended our maturities out to 2020.
Now looking at SBU performance for the quarter, I'll specifically comment on 2 of our businesses, that's Latin America and North America. In our Latin America business, we had a great quarter, particularly in Brazil, although we need to disaggregate the numbers to fully appreciate our progress. Darren will review the results in more detail, but our Latin America business is essentially flat year-over-year despite a significant reduction in our Venezuelan operating income resulting from the currency devaluation there. The difference was made up by the remainder of the region where our Brazilian business led the way.
Brazil continues to be a common bright spot for many companies this earnings season. And for Goodyear, our Brazilian business has been a longtime industry leader with a leading distribution channel, world-class low-cost manufacturing and a dedicated customer base looking to grow profitably together with us. We remain well positioned to take advantage of the stability in Brazil and we see a path to continued profitable growth in the future.
Last quarter, I laid out the path to a 5% segment operating income margin in our North America business. I'm very pleased that both our third quarter results and more importantly, the actions that drove them as the impact of those actions goes well beyond the quarter. Year-to-date, North America tire is slightly above breakeven and third quarter segment operating income surpassed the prior year despite significant raw material headwinds.
The success of our new product engine drove a 7% revenue per tire increase. Our fill rates in North America Consumer business remain lower than we would like. They are indicative of what remains a supply constraint to industry environment, getting low inventories coming out of the recession. An improving OE business, which I think you know is contractually preference over our replacement business, also contributes to the replacement business fill rates challenge.
Now in that environment, our orders remained strong, reflective of demand for our branded Goodyear products. And I would also point out that tighter sellout or end consumer demand remains generally below sell into the channel. And as the U.S. economy improves, we would expect consumer demand to improve, offering additional growth opportunities for our business.
Now in addition to improved price/mix, our North American business remains focused both improve its operating efficiency and improving the mix of tires they produce. Ultimately, our supply chain goal is to efficiently make only the right tires, thereby reducing investment in inventory while simultaneously improving our fill rates and we're making progress. 
Our planned leverage has certainly been improving as the industry volumes rebound. However, we also continue to drive productivity by producing more from our existing assets as well. I recently visited our factory in Fayetteville, North Carolina where we make many of our newest products and where I saw examples of double-digit productivity improvements being achieved. This is an excellent example of what is possible under our 2009 labor contract with the United Steelworkers who have been and will be instrumental in achieving these gains.
While we obviously have more work to do in North America am I that visit game even more confidence in our ability to drive further productivity in our domestic factories.
Now as you look behind the Q3 highlights numbers, I thought it might be beneficial to talk about specific focus areas that likely align closely about the future. The first area is raw materials, not surprisingly. The biggest question you may have is whether we can offset the historic increases we have been experiencing. And my answer to you is absolutely, we can. When you think about the raw material headwinds we've been facing recently, the one with the most volatility right now and consequently significant focus of our efforts. 
Now historically composing more than 25% of our total raw material cost, the range of prices over the past 2 years has been from $0.60 per pound to the current high of around $1.80 which in our view, makes little sense. As we evaluate the market, we know that usage is increasing globally as economies recover from the recession and emerging markets continue their growth. We continue to see ample supply to support our business needs, keeping in mind that usage in the industry is still below 2007 and 2008 levels. We also know the number of new plantings has increased significantly over the past several years and is expected to continue.
And over the past year, unfavorable weather conditions in Southeast Asia where most of the natural rubber supply is produced, has driven the perception that supplies will tighten. And the futures market also had limited liquidity. For example, physical rubber going through the Singapore exchange represents only about 1% of the tonnage used each year.
So it stands to reason in our opinion that the combination of rising demand and the perceived impact of weather on supply drives speculation. So you can think about the rubber markets as one where supply and demand may be playing a role but where we believe speculation has taken prices well above levels that make any sense to us. 
Now that said, in response to the historic high pricing, we're continuing to aggressively substitute synthetic rubber for natural rubber where possible. We believe we have the best ability in the industry to substitute synthetic rubber in our compounds and we've increased technical resources to identify additional substitution opportunities.
We also are aggressively pursuing alternative raw materials such as BioIsoprene developed in partnership with GenCorp. We introduced the concept tire last year in Copenhagen featuring this compound, and we are collaborating with -- to produce quantities by mid-2011 level that will support production of test tires. And of course, we're continuing to focus on price/mix opportunities as we have historically done in the face of increasing raw material costs.
Now the second area you may be questioning is the sustainability of price/mix. Our confidence in our ability to continue to deliver price/mix is tied directly to our innovation, the strength of our new product engine and decisions we are making as we selectively focus on profitable growth opportunities. 
And as you think about this, remember that mix is not only driven by products but business mix as well. We continue to receive awards and third-party recognitions that drive differentiation in the marketplace and ultimately translate into consumer demand for our premium branded products. Goodyear Assurance Fuel Max, a low rolling resistance fuel savings tire we introduced in North America last year has already sold more than 3 million units and was recently given the good housekeeping seal. This product is a clear winner in a segment where demand continues to stay ahead of supply.
Also in North America, our Goodyear Eagle F1 asymmetric tire and our Dunlop SP Sport Maxx GT tire finished one and two among 21 competitive tires in the ultrahigh summer performance category testing. and earned a best buy recommendation from a leading U.S. consumer publication. 
And we've got great product used in Europe as well. We achieved unprecedented success in recently completed winter tire tests that are clear critical to the consumer purchase decision. In fact, I would go so far as to say that our Goodyear and Dunlop tires dominated the German winter tire test leaderboard. Goodyear Dunlop had a number one tire in eight of the nine early German test results in every one of those tests, our tires were evaluated as highly recommendable. And most remarkable are the results from a 16 million member motor club and a respected independent research firm where we placed 4 of our products among the top 5. No competitor was even close to our levels of success.
And that success is extremely significant as winter tires comprised of approximately 25% of the replacement market in Europe and the category will likely continue to grow. Furthermore, top positioning in the all-important medicine tasks directly correlate to consumer demand and purchase intent. Our part and innovation in new product are not limited to the consumer segment only. I'm also pleased to report that our development of a brand new 63-inch OTR we expect to ship it later this quarter. I'm confident these tires will deliver the performance and users are looking for in the mining industry as these markets continue their rebound.
Now these new products demonstrate the technical advantage Goodyear brings to the industry by innovating, designing, manufacturing and marketing the most technically advanced tires in the world.
And we combined these products successes to our selective mix strategy as well. For example, in North America, we took the Kelly brand national, replacing private label offerings and improving our product mix in branded share. And another example is our continued OE selectivity where we rigorously balance volumes and profitability versus our consumer replacement business where in many cases, we continue to have backorders. Mix versus volume orientation will remain an important part of our business strategy going forward.
Now the final area I'll cover is our investment plans. We see significant opportunities in the tire industry as our markets continue to grow and as consumers demand increasing levels of tire technology. Those opportunities offer high return investment alternatives. To make certain, we're capitalizing on those profitable growth opportunities that will help as take to new levels, goodyear continues to pursue investment strategy focused on 3 areas, increasing our low cost footprint, improving our ability to supply tires with increasing levels of consumer relevant technology and driving profitable growth in emerging or growing markets.
We increased our level of CapEx this year to more than $1 billion to address the growth opportunities that we've targeted. This level of investment is about $400 million above the level to sustain our existing business. As we consider these investments, we also performed a risk assessment of future demand. The tire industry is a cyclical industry typically following GDP trends and the data supports that, too. So as the economy recovers as well, so we'll the time to seek and as I said, we're actually seeing that trend happen.
We also see 2 significant differences in what's happening from the recent economic downturn versus previous recessions. The first is the continued strong and now sustainable growth and increased relevance of emerging markets, particularly the BRIC countries where GDP and car park growth continue at high single-digit or double-digit rates. 
A shift has taken place where we now see a trend of growth for these markets continuing for an extended period of time with any disruption slightly slowing rather than reversing their underlying growth trends. In the past, these markets were arguably more volatile.
The second difference from previous recessions is the increasing complexity of tire construction and higher demands on tire performance. These changes are driven by trends such as a focus on low rolling resistance for greater fuel economy by not trendy wet traction, noise or tread wear. Increasing type complexity and performance expectations will create demand for new products, I would suggest even in future periods of economic slowdown. This is particularly true in mature markets where tire performance continues to drive consumer purchases. The Assurance Fuel Max is a good example of this. 
And tire labeling will further drive future complexity as performance thresholds and specific categories will be spelled out on the products with clear consumer awareness.
This trend, which we believe this year to stay represents the most significant change to the tire industry in decades. It will place a premium on innovative technology and manufacturing capabilities to deliver premium tires that meet this new performance criteria.
So as the economy recovers, as emerging markets drive more sustainable growth and a status of meat the new levels a performance requirements, the solid underpinnings of a growing tire industry with a trend toward increased but a product differentiation are certainly firmly planted.
With both the opportunities and risks in mind, we are pursuing 2 major investments that will increase our capacity in low cost locations. The relocation and expansion of our Dalian, China and the expansion and modernization of our factory outside Santiago, Chile. Both of these investments will come online beginning in 2011 and will increasingly add to capacity over the next 3 to 4 years.
We also have 2 U.S. locations undergoing major upgrades to produce additional HVA tires in Oklahoma and our Fayetteville, North Carolina plants. These upgrades are already adding to our ability to meet customer demand and it will add more value over the coming years. While capital is clearly important to our growth, our philosophy remains to first get more of the right output from our existing assets. Second, to use third-party supply as we do selectively for non-Goodyear branded tires and third, only then do we consider capital expenditures as a way forward.
We see the investments we are making as addressing the parts of the market where we are going to play while balancing that with a focus on cash flow and our capital structure.
In summary, when you think about the third quarter, combined with our prospects for the future, keep in mind the volumes are improving, our products are succeeding, the headwinds we face can and are being managed. We make tangible progress in our North America business. We're managing and improving our capital structure, and we're investing where we strongly believe we will get the highest impact and the most profitable return.
We are doing precisely what we want to do and we feel very confident about our future direction. Now with that, I'll turn the call over to Darren to take a closer look at the details of the quarter. Darren?

headline: Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Rich, and good morning, everyone. Our third quarter financial results continue to demonstrate strong performance in each of our businesses. Absent the impact of the spike in raw materials, results would have been better than anytime in recent hist
componenttext:
Thanks, Rich, and good morning, everyone. Our third quarter financial results continue to demonstrate strong performance in each of our businesses. Absent the impact of the spike in raw materials, results would have been better than anytime in recent history. 
This show the benefit of our reductions in fixed cost, as well as the improved business and product mix and still there's more opportunity as we further benefit from greater factory utilization and have time to fully offset raw material costs going forward. So third quarter results continue to demonstrate progress required to achieve our next stage metrics.
Taking a look at the income statement, our unit sales globally increased by 6% and revenue increased 13% in Q3, reflecting improvement in global tire demand, as well as improved price/mix. Once again this quarter, each business unit exceeded 2009 unit sales in revenues.
Segment operating income in the quarter was $234 million. Price/mix benefits of $252 million were among the highest we've seen over the past several years and led to an increase in revenue per tire of 8%. Our ability to achieve price/mix at this level reflects the continued success of our brands and innovative products in the marketplace and strategic decisions to focus sales in the most profitable brands and distribution channels.
We experienced higher raw material cost of $412 million, an increase of 30%, consistent with our expectations. The 2009 period reflected the low point in the raw material cycle. Natural rubber bottomed out in 2009 at about $0.60 per pound versus around $1.30 at the end of June and about $1.80 today. While successful at offsetting raw materials over time, during short periods of rapid escalation like we saw in the third quarter, the benefits of price/mix don't always match up.
Looking at the sequential comparison, that is the comparison between the third quarter and the second quarter of this year, we increased segment operating income despite over $150 million sequential increase in raw material costs. We were able to do this by nearly offsetting the sequential raw material cost increase through price/mix improvements. 
I should mention that our year-to-date price/mix remains about $220 million ahead of raw material cost. We're confident our strategy will allow us to offset raw material cost increases over time and there's nothing in the market we see today that will change our confidence.
Focusing next on volume, year-over-year tire sales increased by 2.7 million units in the quarter and higher production levels drove an improvement in non-absorbed fixed cost. With production levels in Q2 up about 6.5 million units from the prior year, the amount of unabsorbed fixed cost in Q3 was $75 million lower than a year ago after considering the one quarter lag. 
On a per unit basis, this is slightly below our guidance of $12 to $14 per unit as consumer production has come back faster than commercial production. On a year-to-date basis, we've been recovering around $12 per tire.
While not broken out separately, our other tire-related businesses provided only a small benefit in the quarter as raw material pressures affected these businesses as well.
In the third quarter, we realized about $70 million of cost savings, raising the total to about $350 million through the first 3 quarters. Unlike the second quarter, where the savings were weighted toward headcount reductions versus a year ago, this quarter we saw savings focused in the area of raw material costs, given the significance of that challenge to our business. Of the $70 million cost achieved, savings achieved, over $30 million was a result of efforts to take advantage of lower-cost sources, substitute lower-cost materials in our compounds and to reduce the amount of material required to produce each tire.
While our third quarter cost savings remain consistent with our plan we are driving to add this performance going forward as we further improve manufacturing efficiency, take planned footprint actions in high cost locations, see the benefit of 7-day operations in our meeting plant and continue to drive further back office consolidation.
As anticipated, pension expense continued to decline in our North American business in the third quarter. Currency hurt our international earnings, primarily reflecting the effects of the devaluation in Venezuela and the weaker euro versus the U.S. dollar. The euro fell 8% versus last year to an average of $1.31 in the quarter although reason trends are more favorable. 
While not broken out in the chart, actions taken in Venezuela to improve business results since the devaluation are having a positive impact and reduced the year-over-year effect in Q3. I'll update you on the situation on Venezuela as I discuss the business unit results.
As we turn to the balance sheet, you see that working capital increased about $500 million, reflecting seasonal factors related partly to winter tire sales together with higher raw material costs and pressure from improved demand. Q3 typically reflects cash usage to increase working capital ahead of cash inflows in Q4. 
As we stated previously, for the full year, we expect working capital to be a use of no more than $200 million. Looking at our debt maturity profile, we completed several transactions in the quarter that collectively eliminated bond maturities between now and 2016. In August, we issued a total of $1 billion of 8.25 senior notes with a maturity of 2020. The proceeds were used during September to repay $713 million of notes coming due in 2011 and $260 million of notes due in 2015. This now leaves us with no significant maturities other than the refinancing of our secured credit facilities over the next 5 years.
On the last conference call, we commented that we're in the process of evaluating the new pension relief legislation. The pension relief legislation, which was signed into law on June 25, allows companies to reduce near-term pension funding by allowing unfunded amounts to be funded over longer periods of time than the standard 7 years. 
During Q3, we completed a complex and comprehensive analysis of the alternatives offered under this legislation. The rules and requirements related to each alternative, the impact on beneficiaries of each of the plants and the cash flow impact the changes in contributions would provide. This analysis was conducted for each of Goodyear's 6 U.S. qualified pension plans. Using this analysis we elected a 9-year tradition, also known as 2+7. As a result, we now expect our U.S. contributions in 2011 to be about at about 2010 levels. Remember that we have been expecting an increase in 2011 of about $250 million. Our expected U.S. contributions for 2010 remain unchanged at $200 million to $225 million. Future years will also benefit from that.
Turning to the segment results, North America reported segment operating income of $5 million for the quarter, which compares to income of $2 million in the same quarter of 2009. Sales in 2010 reached $2.2 billion, an increase of 17% over last year. This increase in sales was supported by a 5% increase in unit volume, with 18 million units sold in Q3. 
The results in North America reflect the continued operating improvement in the face of substantial raw material costs. Despite $148 million in raw material cost increases, North American tire was able to use earnings results above prior year levels. Our strategy of focusing on growth in our branded tire business, specifically the Goodyear Dunlop and Kelly brands, helped us increase replacement sales in Q3 versus the prior year, even though the consumer replacement industry was down 6% in the same period.
As a result, we again gained branded share and grew share in total. I'll remind everyone that the third quarter of 2009 had sell-in levels with tire makers reselling to dealers at higher rates prior to the imposition of tariffs on Chinese imports in late September last year. The impact on Q4 was the opposite and volumes were artificially low in Q4 last year following the implementation of the tariff.
The Consumer OE industry experienced strong year-over-year growth, with an increase of 18% in the quarter despite 2009's third quarter sales being aided by government incentives. Commercial talked industry conditions continue the trend of improvement, with the replacement industry increasing by 14%. 
Freight tonnage increased by 5% in September over the 2009 levels. September marked the 10th consecutive month of year-over-year gains given by improving economic activity and inventory restocking across sectors. Commercial OE industry volumes improved by 35% on strong truck bills.
North America's revenue per tire increased by 7% over 2009 on the effect of price increases to offset higher raw material costs and overall favorable product mix. Strong OE sales growth serve to reduce the benefit of improvement as good as volume comes at the expense of higher margin replacement business. North America earnings improved and higher sales volumes, improved conversion costs, which reflect the benefit of fixed costs recovery on our production as well as lower pension cost. These year-over-year gains were partially offset by raw material cost inflation exceeding price and mix improvements.
We recently announced price increases of up to 6% in consumer and up to 8% in commercial, both effective October 1 to combat further raw material headwinds. Although the full impact of our price increases will not be felt until Q1 given backorders and lower seasonal volume in Q4. Europe, Middle East and Africa reported segment operating income of $77 million in the quarter, which compares to $106 million in the 2009 period. The 2010 results reflect sales of $1.7 billion and volume of 19.1 million units, a 7% increase in both sales and unit volumes. Industry growth was solid in the quarter. The consumer replacement tire industry was stronger versus prior year, driven by strong winter tire demand. This was partially offset by Consumer OE, which decreased 5% driven by a pull ahead in sales in the first half, ahead of the termination of government incentives.
The commercial replacement tire industry grew by 13% and the commercial organization rebounded with industry volumes almost double a year ago. EMEA sales growth reflected an improving economy, new innovative products and stronger business mix, coupled with price increases to offset higher raw material costs. Revenue per tire, excluding the impact of foreign exchange, increased 7% versus Q3 2009. 
Within the region, strong execution by our team in Eastern Europe resulted in a 17% volume increase versus Q3 '09. We continue to gain market share in Q3 in both consumer and truck in the emerging markets in EMEA. Recall that our sales in the EMEA were also reduced by the termination of our agreement to distribute certain tires produced by Sumitomo rubber, which represented about 1.8 million units in the full year 2009 results. The weaker euro versus a year ago negatively impacted net sales for the quarter by $100 million.
EMEA segment operating income decreased $29 million, mainly driven by higher raw material costs of $154 million. Stronger volume along with price/mix in Q3 partially offset raw material costs. In addition, stronger production volume resulted in a benefit of $32 million from lower unabsorbed fixed costs in the factories.
In Latin America, we reported segment operating income of $95 million on sales revenue of $569 million, which represents a revenue increase of 17% on a 4% increase in unit volume versus the prior year. 
Similar to what we saw in the second quarter, segment operating income compared to a year ago reflected 2 offsetting factors: Our business in Brazil and other countries outside Venezuela increased earnings by $20 million, an outstanding result. This improvement was more than offset by a decrease in earnings in Venezuela of $24 million, which I'll discuss further in a moment.
The increased sales reflect the strong pace of economic improvement in most of the region especially in Brazil where the latest GDP statistics shows second quarter growth of almost 9%. Excluding Venezuela, the consumer replacement industry growth has been robust at nearly 10% and the improvement in OE has been even stronger. The commercial industry volumes increased by than 10% in replacement while commercial OE volumes were up well over 50% versus Q3 last year. Price/mix benefits more than offset higher raw material costs in the quarter while also helping address the currency devaluation in Venezuela.
Coming back to the situation in Venezuela, the adverse environment continue to have a significant impact of segment operating income in Q3. Segment operating income versus 2009 in Venezuela declined by $24 million. Compared to the second quarter however, earnings in Venezuela increased about $13 million. The improvement versus Q2 is driven by both our actions to increase local production of truck tires and pricing actions initiated to offset inflation. To put Q3 in perspective, our Venezuela business is now running on profitability levels last seen in Q4 2009. So good work by the team there.
Our Asia Pacific business reported record third quarter volume in revenue. The fundamentals of the business remain strong as Asia's volumes increased 8% and sales were up 14% versus the same period last year. China and India continue to perform well displaying strong demand, strong mix and market share gains in consumer replacement. 
Segment operating income for the quarter was $57 million. The year-on-year decline in earnings was due primarily to our price/mix improvement of $23 million, not fully offsetting rapidly rising raw material cost increases of $35 million. The impact of these rising raw material costs is particularly acute in Asia. Asia is closer to the natural rubber supply and as lower finished goods inventory. That's the impact of raw material price changes is reflected quickly in Asia's earnings. We remain confident that over time, our Asian team will recover raw material cost increases through price/mix.
Other business segments in the region are also showing strength with record agricultural tire volume in both OE and replacement. OTR segment remained favorable. As part of our debt that to take advantage of growth opportunities in these markets, we continue to make progress on the relocation and expansion of our Dalian, China factory, which once operational will help us continue our growth in China. This new factory will produce its first tires next year and should reach full capacity by 2014.
Our Asia business is an excellent business and as Rick said, we're positioning ourselves for continued success going forward.
So across all our business units, you saw evidence of successful execution of our strategies, continued volume growth, improving price/mix, benefits from higher factory utilization and strong performance in both our consumer and our commercial businesses.
Turning now to our outlook for the remainder of the year, we've updated our views, including our expectations for industry volumes and raw materials. As you can see on Slide 21, industry volumes continue to be a good story. We continue to expect growth in the key market segments for North America and Europe and have increased our expectations somewhat. 
The impact of tariffs on Chinese tires last year in Q4 creates an easy comp so consumer replacement industry volumes in North America will be stronger than the full year average. Alternatively consumer replacement in Europe during Q4 is expected to be down a few percentage points versus prior year. Commercial volumes in both regions during Q4 will be in line or better than our full year guidance.
Looking at raw materials, natural rubber prices have increased measurably since our call in July. While this is not a factor in Q3 given the lag in inventory, there will be a moderate impact in Q4. Raw materials are now expected to increase at least 35% in Q4 versus the prior year compared to our previous expectation of about 30%. And action on pricing, so that the year-over-year difference in price/mix versus raws we saw in Q3 would only widen slightly in Q4. We expect this to further improve during the first half of 2011 provided the rate of raw material price increases moderates as our price increases take full effect.
For modeling purposes we now expect 2010 interest expense to be about $325 million. We reconfirm our prior guidance of a 25% to 30% tax rate on foreign segment operating income. The third quarter at 30% was at the top of the range with the same expected for Q4. If you recall, on the last call, we said that the tax rate in the second half will be higher than what we experienced in the first half. They provide a range to reflect the fact of the calculated rate could move from quarter-to-quarter and depending on the geographic split of profitability.
Our outlook for CapEx remains unchanged with a significant level of investment expected to be completed in Q4. As we look to Q4 and beyond, you can expect our progress to continue. We remain very positive regarding long-term prospects for our business. Global growth and continued demand for higher technology tires provide significant opportunity for Goodyear. This will allow us to continue to improve our operating results, leveraging our richer mix of products, shift our lower cost manufacturing footprint and growth in emerging markets.
Now we'll open the call up for Q&A.

headline: Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

headline: Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. And I guess maybe just a little bit more color on how we should be thinking about the North American margins going forward, the volumes obviously have come off the bottom, you're facing a pretty intense raw material cost headwind and you're going to
componenttext: Okay. And I guess maybe just a little bit more color on how we should be thinking about the North American margins going forward, the volumes obviously have come off the bottom, you're facing a pretty intense raw material cost headwind and you're going to be adding some pricing here but it sounds like raw materials equally continue to go up into Q4 and maybe even into Q1. How should we be thinking about this trajectory to get to 5%? Can you just maybe give us a couple of components of a bridge from this breakeven level that you're at right now?

headline: Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Rod. I think if we go back to what we said last quarter, it's probably a good place to start. And I would tell you our confidence from what we said last quarter hasn't diminished at all. In fact I might say that it's even increased given that as we l
componenttext: Yes, Rod. I think if we go back to what we said last quarter, it's probably a good place to start. And I would tell you our confidence from what we said last quarter hasn't diminished at all. In fact I might say that it's even increased given that as we look to North America, we improved quarter-to-quarter despite a significant raw material headwind. So in other words, we have said that headwind with strong price/mix and cost savings. So I think from a trajectory perspective, we feel pretty good about where we're going. If we look broadly speaking about the path to 5%, again I will tell you we see volumes increasing both in terms of margin and in terms of overhead recovery. Remember we really haven't seen much of the truck business come back yet or at least in a way that the consumer markets have come back. We'll continue to be aggressive on price/mix versus raw materials with our goal of offsetting it and as you know, when we have periods of these high raw material cost in a quarter like that, price/mix lags a little bit but ultimately will catch up and will offset. And I suggest if that raw material number comes down. Also from a North America perspective, we see incremental cost savings coming in both beyond the plants filling but for some of the cost structure improvements including the USW savings. Remember that's worth $100 million plus as we go forward. And as I mentioned, last quarter, we also contemplate a footprint action as we go forward. And finally, I would say over the long-term, Rod, pensions are something that we've had a significant headwind versus '07. It's getting better, as Darren mentioned on the call. But we have little control over what happens there. As you know, we have not, we stopped new entrants into the hourly plant, we halted our salary plant a while ago. So what we're really dealing with is the impact of asset returns and discount rates and that's going to -- Darren will talk about that a bit as well. But that will actually increase on us as we look to next year and we look at discount rates going down. So between volume price/mix and raw materials, the cost structure actions, footprint actions and pension, that's ultimately how we're going to get there and in terms of trajectory, I would say no change in terms of how we thought about it and we're on a path to do it.

headline: Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: when you think about the raw materials versus the pricing as we go from Q3 to Q4 and then Q4 to Q1, it sounds like raw materials will be the bigger driver as you get into the fourth quarter implies a margin compression? And then you start to make up the d
componenttext: when you think about the raw materials versus the pricing as we go from Q3 to Q4 and then Q4 to Q1, it sounds like raw materials will be the bigger driver as you get into the fourth quarter implies a margin compression? And then you start to make up the difference, do you see the net of those at this point as being a positive and if so, when would that happen?

headline: Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: well, Rod, maybe if I can take a step back and just give a little bit of perspective again. We talk about this on the call and it might be worth just reiterating some of the points. In the quarter, we saw about a little over $400 million or 30% increase i
componenttext: well, Rod, maybe if I can take a step back and just give a little bit of perspective again. We talk about this on the call and it might be worth just reiterating some of the points. In the quarter, we saw about a little over $400 million or 30% increase in headwinds. And that's pretty much where we expected it to go. And again, the driver was natural rubber. Q4, Darren mentioned on the call, will be, now we're looking at least 35% so we will see an increase for the next quarter. And again it's driven by natural rubber being up around $1.80 a pound. But when we look at that, to just give you a way to think about this, we look at the fundamentals of what's driving that price because I think it goes to the long-term of where price/mix catches up with raw materials and eventually reverses itself in terms of price/mix sticking and raw material coming down a little bit. As we look at the raw materials markets, we still struggle to see the cost of the higher raw material costs. Natural rubber clearly is up as the economies are growing. But we also know that there's ample supply out there today and usages aren't even back to where they were in '07 and '08 and plantings have taken place already so we know the supply is growing and yes there's been a lot of bad weather over there. But it really given the perception of a supply disruption but not one that we physically see. So we really don't see the struggle to see the logic in the sense of natural rubber being as high beyond the speculative impact at this point. So that what gives us confidence that it will balance out and reduce over time. But no prediction on when but certainly, that's something that we would anticipate happening just as it did sort of at the end of 2009 and into the beginning of 2010. Now what are we doing about it, you saw in the quarter, we had $252 million of price/mix in the quarter, which is an excellent performance at or near our highest price/mix in any quarter. We had 3 price increases since December of last year. Our new products are out there and supporting those price increases in a significant way. And sequentially, year-over-year, we're down but sequentially we almost offset almost $160 million of cost increases quarter-to-quarter. And in North America, we actually had higher EBIT quarter-over-quarter year-over-year as I mentioned and as a corporation, we came in within $40 million of segment operating income from a year ago, offsetting almost all of that $400 million increase. So we still see raw materials going up, but we're doing the actions on the product and price side. And we redoubled the efforts on product substitution, looking at the weight of the tires, looking at new materials that we're going to put it here. Of course, we'll continue to revisit price/mix and of course we'll continue to take cost out in other places. So I think we're doing all the right things, and successfully doing the right things to deal with it, and over the next couple of quarters, again, with the way of raw materials turn, you know we're going to have a headwind but we think we're doing the right things to catch up to it, stay ahead of it ultimately. So that's how we think about it, Q4 will be a headwind. If you think about rolling over Q1, we're not giving any guidance on, but rollover is about 6 months particularly in North America, a little over 6 months. And so we're going to be with the raw materials, but there's nothing out there that we see we really can't manage.

headline: Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

And as a data point what your year-to-date pension performance has been and my last question is you're seeing a lot of competitors raising capital and ramping up capital spending a lot of that is going to emerging markets. Are there any implications for Goodyear at this point from this are for the industry is there anything that would concern you in terms of relative spending levels?

headline: Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

componenttext: Let me have Darren address the pension cost and I'll talk about the investments.

headline: Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, so on pension, we've got 2 issues. One is a funding issue, and the other is the impact on the P&L. You heard us say on the call that from a funding perspective, we benefited from elections we've made in the funding relief program. So that now instead
componenttext: Yes, so on pension, we've got 2 issues. One is a funding issue, and the other is the impact on the P&L. You heard us say on the call that from a funding perspective, we benefited from elections we've made in the funding relief program. So that now instead of expecting a $250 million increase in funding next year, we're expecting funding levels in 2011 at about the same level as 2010. If we add, take that though, that means we're contributing last, which net-net does create an additional expense. Because we have fewer assets in the plan, but if we look at where we are year-to-date, we'd now, through September 30, have a 7% return on our portfolio. So close knit on the 8.5% return that we assume for the purposes of our calculations and our full review of expenses. So the 7% return is obviously helpful, it's better than where we've been. I think we're in pretty good shape there. The last thing we'll have to think about is look forward is the discount rate, and if we look at discount rates at the end of September, they were down around 80 basis points from where we were at the end of last year. And that will start to have an effect on 2011 expense, not to the second quarter next year given the lag in inventory that. But to look at that and we'd say we're going to continue to get benefit from lower pension expense through the fourth quarter and through the first quarter. And then the impact of the lower discount rates will start to hit us in Q2. So I think the outlook on pension ultimately is benefit in Q1, similar to what we've been seeing. And then an increase in Q2 through Q4 next year of a lesser amount. So ultimately not much change in 2011 versus 2010.

headline: Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And Rod, on the investment side, I'll just tell you, we see again very significant opportunities in the tire industry growing around the globe. And we also see the demand for, as I mentioned, the increasing technology in the tires that are going to be sol
componenttext: And Rod, on the investment side, I'll just tell you, we see again very significant opportunities in the tire industry growing around the globe. And we also see the demand for, as I mentioned, the increasing technology in the tires that are going to be sold. And in that environment I would say our investment priorities remain very consistent and that's to increase our low-cost manufacturing capabilities. And also improving our ability to supply those tires that consumers one with a consumer relevant technology. And also driving profitable growth in emerging markets. And that the margins add, we see those, we see great opportunities for growth in emerging markets. But again, we're going to be focused on profitable growth in our targeted segments. In those segments, we have consistently defined as where Goodyear brand and technology offer a very strong value proposition. That's where our focus would be. We took our investment, our CapEx up to $1 billion. We're expanding low cost facilities in China, in Latin America and Chile. And we're upgrading our factories in North America to make more of those tires that the market wants. And I would just say, notwithstanding what other companies are doing, we remain but a very disciplined CapEx process. And look for high return investments. We think they're investments we're making our high return investments, and we'll balance that off with our focus and cash flow and our capital structure.

headline: Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Patrick Archambault with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Patrick Archambault with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to follow up on the pension question. Two issues, number one is what kind of constraints do you have when you're agreeing to the 2 + 7, I think I remember reading that their were some restrictions on compensation and things like that, that wer
componenttext: Just wanted to follow up on the pension question. Two issues, number one is what kind of constraints do you have when you're agreeing to the 2 + 7, I think I remember reading that their were some restrictions on compensation and things like that, that were sort of tied to utilizing that legislation. And then the other thing, I mean what do you think about, there's been some discussion about it, I mean what do you think about potentially raising equity to try and sort of once and for all reduce the underfunding or do you think that just a combinations of kind of more normalized interest rates and ROAs going back up to parity with your assumption or maybe over will be enough to kind of get you to that funded status you need?

headline: Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think there are questions, let me get the relief legislation first because I think that's a quick one and then they can talk a bit about capital structure and the way that we think about tax. We add pension into our other debt like obligations as we thi
componenttext: I think there are questions, let me get the relief legislation first because I think that's a quick one and then they can talk a bit about capital structure and the way that we think about tax. We add pension into our other debt like obligations as we think about what our leverage is. From a constraint perspective, don't do anything significant with the pension funding relief. There's some provisions in there. I think the ones that you're referring to are provisions that provide that the amount of contribution reduction can be affected in a small way if there is payment of what they deem to be excess compensation, not a significant item for us. We can go through the specifics of that but overall, not a big impact from our perspective.

headline: Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we elect 2.7 relief.
componenttext: Yes, we elect 2.7 relief.

headline: Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: The more important question is how do we deal with its obligation over the long-term? And as we see the discount rates likely coming down although everything is going to be evaluated at year end, we're looking at a discount rate reduction of 75 or 100 bas
componenttext: The more important question is how do we deal with its obligation over the long-term? And as we see the discount rates likely coming down although everything is going to be evaluated at year end, we're looking at a discount rate reduction of 75 or 100 basis points based on things were at September 30. And that's going to add, you could add another $3 million, $4 million, $5 million to the unfunded obligation. And obviously the interest rates can go the other way. I think we will look at the unfunded obligation along with our debts, our debt as being the obligations that we have to deal with. We look to have a capital structure in the long run that would have debt plus our legacy obligations to EBITDA and to be back to legacy expense. But have that ratio be no more than 2.5x. To be able to achieve that metric over time, we'll achieve it by improving earnings. We'll achieve it, I think, hopefully by interest rates normalizing and getting some return on the assets. We'll obviously make contributions to the plan of a time, and that's going to be one of the uses of cash that we have. Although less of an issue for 2011 than it had been. And then I think look at our capital structure in the long run, and we don't put a timetable on this, we wouldn't rule out using capital market transactions to help in the process as we've done in the past. But there's nothing there that specifics timetable and I think we keep all of the alternatives open as we think about how we get there over time.

headline: Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. That's helpful. And one final one, can you tell us a little bit more about your outsourcing strategy. You've talked about some of the -- you're doing in North America to HVA tires. But how much is outsourcing kind of a core part your 5% SOI t
componenttext: Okay, great. That's helpful. And one final one, can you tell us a little bit more about your outsourcing strategy. You've talked about some of the -- you're doing in North America to HVA tires. But how much is outsourcing kind of a core part your 5% SOI target in North America? And I guess you've alluded to a little bit of that with some of your additional footprint actions that you mentioned were sort of likely to happen. So a, kind of how much does this outsourcing model sort of work into your sort of North America manufacturing strategy and over what time period would we be talking about?

headline: Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. So Pat, just to make sure that we're on the same page, you're referring to having third parties produce tires for us?
componenttext: Okay. So Pat, just to make sure that we're on the same page, you're referring to having third parties produce tires for us?

headline: Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: That's correct, yes.
componenttext: That's correct, yes.

headline: Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And that's fine. I think we've talked about in the past as we went through and discussed where our production was last year. That given that the tires that we produce and the tires we sold, we had about 10 million tires produced by third parties. And part
componenttext: And that's fine. I think we've talked about in the past as we went through and discussed where our production was last year. That given that the tires that we produce and the tires we sold, we had about 10 million tires produced by third parties. And partly, that's partners that we have, that we have joint ventures with and partly as third parties or suppliers for us. So I think you start off and say that 10 million tires is a global number. Obviously, some of those would relate to North America. But yes, I think as we go forward, the level of tires that we've had produced, the non-Goodyear brand of tires have been important to us, but not a critical element and if you heard us focus more on branded product as we worked on improving the mix in our business. So I think the things that you were this I don't know if you have anything you would say.

headline: Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: The only thing I would add to it, Darren is right it's not strategic to what we are doing. And the way we think about third-party sourcing and again some of our partners give that to us sort of outside third parties. It's really a different source of a wa
componenttext: The only thing I would add to it, Darren is right it's not strategic to what we are doing. And the way we think about third-party sourcing and again some of our partners give that to us sort of outside third parties. It's really a different source of a way to get tires without having to invest more capital. As I mentioned, our focus is not only getting high return capital investments for the type, for the investments we make the supplier tires, but also to get the most all of the factories that we have. So it's a philosophy and particularly in North America, our first pass is going to be make those branded tires in the factories we have very high efficiencies higher capital with that capital investments to make more of the tires, that's the first priority and that's what we see higher efficiency, higher plant utilization and higher margins on the branded tires that we're going to make out of there. So if you think about it philosophically, that's the path that we're moving on as part of our path to 5%, not an outsourcing strategy to do that. Now in other parts of the world, we've gotten third-party sourcing and we've managed it very effectively. It works when we need volume, and it's manageable when those volume demands go down in the industry fluctuations.

headline: Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Himanshu Patel with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Himanshu Patel with JPMorgan.

headline: Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I wanted to go back to North America a little bit. I understand there's sort of maybe a transitory quarter in terms of the price/mix raw materials spread and over a few quarters maybe, I guess at a basic level your volumes at about $18 million this quarte
componenttext: I wanted to go back to North America a little bit. I understand there's sort of maybe a transitory quarter in terms of the price/mix raw materials spread and over a few quarters maybe, I guess at a basic level your volumes at about $18 million this quarter and if you assume that you -- I think you voluntarily exited about $10 million or so of annual private label volumes, which I'd say that $2.5 million per quarter, you kind of add that back, your business is at about 20 million units of North American volumes pro forma, which is not that far off, it's actually 20.5 is pretty much what your unit volume in the third quarter of '07. And so I guess just at a basic level, it doesn't really sound like volumes are kind of the real issue at this stage. Is there, is the real issue or that it just me to take another bite at the apple in terms of sort of going deeper into North American restructuring? And is that a discussion that you need to have with the unions at this stage?

headline: Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Himanshu, you can answer this, I would tell you, we don't view the union as a hindrance to getting our 5% metric. We signed a contract with them in 2010. That contract gives us the flexibility to do what we think we need to do to drive the business forwar
componenttext: Himanshu, you can answer this, I would tell you, we don't view the union as a hindrance to getting our 5% metric. We signed a contract with them in 2010. That contract gives us the flexibility to do what we think we need to do to drive the business forward. So I think as we look at this, we have a path forward and as you look at, we have a path forward to 5% as I mentioned I won't go through each of the elements. But when you look at not versus '07 and where we are now, remember we still have a commercial business that is not at the level that the production level that we want. So we're carrying along still a significant amount of unabsorbed overhead in the P&L versus '07. We do have a significant amount of higher pension expense going forward. So those fundamental cost issues I think are still there when you look at it versus '07 volumes come back but we still have work to do on the cost structure as we move forward. I think we recognize that and we have plans in place to do that.

headline: Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: So Richard if I can just add a couple of things to that. I think what we're saying for North America is clearly we've got additional cost structure to take out. And we've got flexibility under the contract to do that, both productivity in the existing pla
componenttext: So Richard if I can just add a couple of things to that. I think what we're saying for North America is clearly we've got additional cost structure to take out. And we've got flexibility under the contract to do that, both productivity in the existing plants plus the flexibility. We've got a plant that's unprotected in the contract, and we look at this and say we're going to have to take advantage of every opportunity to cut cost, no question about that. If we come back to the price/mix equation, yes, I don't want to lose the fact that if we're just looking at how things are evolving sequentially, as we move from the second quarter to the third quarter, right, the cost from quarter-to-quarter increased over $150 million. We were still able to raise our increase our segment operating income as a company over that time frame. So we're finding ways and granted some of it's price/mix in the case of the second to third, we're able to almost offset that $150 million of raw material costs that we're finding other ways including cost savings to make up the difference. So I think, we take a lot of satisfaction in the fact that we were able to hit that trend, improve our earnings from Q2 to Q3.

headline: Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Himanshu, I just want to add one other quick point. And that's that when we look at North America we're looking at it in the aggregate and we don't split out each of the businesses, consumer commercial what have you. But I will say when we look at the Con
componenttext: Himanshu, I just want to add one other quick point. And that's that when we look at North America we're looking at it in the aggregate and we don't split out each of the businesses, consumer commercial what have you. But I will say when we look at the Consumer business, both replacement and OE between our ability to address price, our mix changes, which are very significantly referenced on the call with a focus on business mix changes from products to channels, all those types of things are working very effectively for us. We're very, I would tell you, we're doing an excellent job of getting price in the Consumer business as well. And when I look at that, very confident in where we're going in our biggest segment of that, of our North American business. Truck is still lagging, I mentioned that and it sort of mutes some of the bigger successes we're having in the Consumer business.

headline: Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

componenttext: And you guys in the past have, I think, indicated that you've got about 17 million units of annual commercial vehicle production capacity. Could you just update us on kind of what your production rate was annualized in Q3 relative to that level?

headline: Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: So Himanshu, our peak was selling about 17 million units a year. And through the middle of this year, we've gotten ourselves back up to a level of about 14 million units run rate. And it's roughly still where we are. So we still got some significant oppor
componenttext: So Himanshu, our peak was selling about 17 million units a year. And through the middle of this year, we've gotten ourselves back up to a level of about 14 million units run rate. And it's roughly still where we are. So we still got some significant opportunity to go up from here, both in terms of sales of Commercial Truck tires. But very importantly, the utilization of the Commercial Truck factories, which is, they are still operating even as we ramped up production globally we're still something like 3/4 of, only utilizing 3/4 of our capacity for commercial trucks.

headline: Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: But also Himanshu all trending in the right direction, we see significant increases in the OE business globally. That's still off a high base or coming off to a lower then working its way back up. And the commercial replacement businesses are trending in
componenttext: But also Himanshu all trending in the right direction, we see significant increases in the OE business globally. That's still off a high base or coming off to a lower then working its way back up. And the commercial replacement businesses are trending in the right direction as well.

headline: Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, could you help us a little bit with the pace of cost savings that we should start thinking about over the next few quarters? You mentioned that there is some difference in the sources of cost savings in Q3 versus H1. How do those kind of i
componenttext: Okay. And then, could you help us a little bit with the pace of cost savings that we should start thinking about over the next few quarters? You mentioned that there is some difference in the sources of cost savings in Q3 versus H1. How do those kind of items interplay over the next few quarters and just directionally, should we think about the pace of cost saving sort of being where we were in Q3 or sort of going back to where we were in with H1?

headline: Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Himanshu it's a good question. I would tell you we still very strongly about our proven track record of driving significant cost savings in all areas of the business. And I can tell that we remain a very significant focus for us as we go forward. Yea
componenttext: Yes, Himanshu it's a good question. I would tell you we still very strongly about our proven track record of driving significant cost savings in all areas of the business. And I can tell that we remain a very significant focus for us as we go forward. Year-to-date, worth about $350 million in cost savings and that keeps us on track to the $1 billion target that we put out there over the 3-year period '10 to '12. So we feel very much that we're on track with our goal. Now as you rightly point out, we had about $70 million in the third quarter, a lot of that was this quarter weighted toward some of the raw material substitution in raw material savings that we did as opposed to second quarter where it was more weighted towards the benefit of headcount reduction that we took in the prior year. The other portion of the savings that we had in the quarter still relates to a big focus that we have around manufacturing efficiency through our low-cost sourcing, through a lot of the continuous improvement, think the Lean-Six Sigma initiatives that we have on getting the standards in place with the USW contract and realizing the savings that that contract offer to us. Also, continuing to focus on SATs savings from back office efficiencies that we put in various places around the globe. So I would tell you we feel good about where we're at. But I would also tell you we're not going to stop there. We need to continue to get more savings out. That's where our focus is. We're focused on getting more efficiencies out of the factories now and implementing our Goodyear operating system. As Darren mentioned, there's plenty of footprint actions around the globe. And we continue to get more volume back, which we should get more efficiency down as we get to seven-day operations. So all said, customers were at but we are not going to stop their rate both in the materials side and the efficiency side.

componenttext: Ravi, I can tell you, I think we were ahead about 8% increase, 7% in North America, 8% overall. 7% increase in North American tires. So I have to say we're very pleased with it. I think we did a good job driving that going forward. And in terms of Latin America, I would tell you Latin America is a combination of aggressive price/mix given the raw material headwinds they've had, driving our cost down. You'll see our SAG there continues to be below 10%. And the price/mix, they will be driven by new product portfolio there. I think we've got about a 75% turnover of new products in the region. And that's helping drive not only demand and volume but also getting what we believe is the right value in the marketplace for those products. And we continually say tough circumstances in Latin America, a lot of volatility from time to time but our team does a very good job managing through that.
